[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): Ammes poses no actual threat, and Echuilles and Geneaux can easily be dealt with (especially when utilizing the latter's weakness to fire). Gui, on the other hand, with its regenerating [Cognizant Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CognizantLimbs), can take a while to actually defeat, especially if the player hasn't been taking [Level Grinding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LevelGrinding) seriously and/or relying too much on Aeons.

[Zerg Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZergRush): Multiple Ammes burst out of Sin when it shows up in Dream Zanarkand, and even more Sinscales burst out of them. Tidus and Auron find themselves surrounded by dozens of Sinscales, but they only have to fight those who are blocking their way "forward" (or rather, where Auron wants to take Tidus).

[Amazing Technicolor Battlefield](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazingTechnicolorBattlefield): Her lair is in the bowels of an abandoned temple/blitzball stadium in the ruins of Zanarkand, yet for some reason when you confront her the party is apparently transported to a stone platform floating in space.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Subverted in that it is plausible for the characters to infer that she genuinely believed there was no definitive method to vanquish Sin. In this perspective, providing Spira with momentary flickers of hope could appear to be the sole path to attain peace. However, her actions (unknown to anyone who operates outside of Bevelle's governance), such as pushing the Yu Yevon agenda, and establishing the Summoner-Final Aeon framework, undoubtedly made her responsible for an extensive cycle of death.

[Attractive Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttractiveZombie): She is an unsent, which is a type of undead technically closest to zombie. She is also [Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice).

[Avenging the Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvengingTheVillain): Lord Zaon, who was last seen among the mirages in Zanarkand, was the husband and guardian to Lady Yunalesca, the first High Summoner. Zaon became the first "Final Aeon" to be sacrificed to Sin. Keep in mind that his Chamber was inert, as the Fayth was lost. It's unclear how both he and Yunalesca wound up beneath Bevelle as unsent. (Yunalesca was killed by Yuna, but her husband was consumed by Yu Yevon. Perhaps his soul was freed when Yu Yevon fled into another body, but that's conjecture.) He and Yunalesca share an embrace before she fights you in the Via Infinito. When she is beaten and dispersed, Zaon walks away, destroyed. He resurfaces in the next boss chamber as a gold-plated Weapon (Paragon), evoking his gold armor.

[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): Her backstory is a mystery, but the original Final Aeon was created from her husband and guardian, Lord Zaon.
    - The canon novel Final Fantasy X-2.5 ~Eien no Daishō~ added some insight into her character backstory, which remains consistent with this trope. Though, it's evident in the book that she had always been a villain, much like her father.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). Her function is to reveal the [Awful Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwfulTruth) to ascendant summoners and help them fulfill the final steps of their journey; and as far as Mika is concerned — himself the [Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood) to the average Spiran — killing her is as good as throwing the world away. For all that, her Final Summoning ritual is a deeply flawed concept and has perpetuated a cycle of death for a millennium. From a narrative structure though, she's [The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy), being the one responsible for much of the problems, but not being directly involved as the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), or the [Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain).

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Considered a legend for being the first summoner of the Final Aeon. Then it turns out that she is the one who has kept a tradition that spans 1,000 years and caused countless people to sacrifice their lives for nothing going.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): The Ultimania and Maechen both speculate that Yunalesca, and possibly even Yu Yevon himself, used the myths around Sin to create what became the Yevonite religion and ensure that Yu Yevon could continue to summon Dream Zanarkand.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): An even bigger one than Seymour Natus was back in Bevelle, in both senses of the trope; not only are the stakes raised immensely upon confronting her, but Yunalesca is widely considered to be one of the hardest bosses in the game.
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): Her physical attacks consist of using her gorgon form's skull hair. She zombifies with them too.

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): Infamously, Chac's Stone Glare *ignores* Stoneproof and Ribbon. The party wouldn't be able to have such a "Proof"-bypassing ability, nor does any other enemy for that matter.
[Cozy Voice for Catastrophes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CozyVoiceForCatastrophes): Tells you some of the most horrifying things regarding Sin and Yevon, in a very calm and comforting voice.

[Daddy's Little Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaddysLittleVillain): Sin began destroying indiscriminately, so Yu Yevon's daughter Yunalesca formed a plan to temporarily subdue it. She used a close bond, that of her her husband Lord Zaon, to turn him into a fayth and summoned the Final Aeon. But Yu Yevon possessed the Final Aeon, made it Sin's new core, and began to rebuild it. Yunalesca knows this, and is perpetuating the "spiral of death".
[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): She is a challenging foe, not afraid to get down and dirty.

[Disc-One Final Dungeon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalDungeon): Invoked, where the grand Yevon tradition of summoner pilgrimages must come to an end with meeting her at the ruins of Zanarkand. Yuna and her Guardians follow through with the tradition until they find out the truth from Yunalesca herself, and, after defeating her, they resolve to find another way to defeat Sin.
[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): She crosses it before she dies, as is shown in how she believes that there is no hope for Spira without the Final Aeon.

[Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanService): Despite being a 1,000-year-old [Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination) she first appears to the party as a beautiful woman who is [practically naked](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific). Once you start fighting her, [though](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanDisservice)...
[Fashionable Asymmetry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FashionableAsymmetry): While most of her outfit matches from left to right, the only unbalanced part of her outfit is her legband on her left leg.

[Good Powers, Bad People](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodPowersBadPeople): Her hardest-hitting attacks are all healing spells, which work quite well considering [her habit of zombifying the party.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie)
[Gorgeous Gorgon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GorgeousGorgon): Her third stage shows her real powerful form which is a giant gorgon head with hair that resembles human skulls.
[Hair Antennae](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairAntennae): Though nowhere near as extreme as Seymour's.

[Hero Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroKiller): She didn't kill Auron directly. Enraged after the [Senseless Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice) of Braska and Jecht, he charged at her in a blind fury, an attack she [easily rebuffed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoHoldsBarredBeatdown) causing him serious injuries to which he would eventually succumb after making his way to Bevelle from Zanarkand.

[Holy Is Not Safe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyIsNotSafe): She's a revered figure in the Yevonite religion, she rules over an abandoned city [held sacred by most Spirans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyGround), and she uses mostly white magic - but she is [pitiless toward those who do not accept her "gift"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) and will still [kill you dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie).

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): As she will reveal once she decides to destroy the party. Despite looking human at first, she's the oldest known Unsent, and can transform into two additional forms that give her increased powers.

[Keeper of Forbidden Knowledge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KeeperOfForbiddenKnowledge): She's the one who bestows knowledge of the [true nature of Sin and the sacrifice needed to defeat it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwfulTruth) on summoners who prove themselves worthy by making it to her lair in the Zanarkand ruins.

[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): As with all major Yevonite figures. Her dialogue reveals that she's deeply cynical about humanity's ability to aspire to anything better, and that her lies and manipulation are necessary to keep the people of Spira in line. Worse, she honestly thinks her actions are in the right, making her willing to kill anyone who tries to stop her.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): She has her own version of the Hymn of the Fayth that has a reverb to it as well as sounding much more sinister in general.
[Life Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDrain): One of her more damaging attacks in her initial phase.

[Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill): When Yuna [refuses to obey her command to choose a sacrifice for the Final Summoning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu), she determines to give the party one.
QUOTE  **Yunalesca:** Poor creature. You would throw away hope? Well...I will free you before you can drown in your own sorrow. It is better to die in hope than to live in despair. Let me be your liberator.

tropeName: Names to Run Away from Really Fast
tropeNotes: [Names to Run Away from Really Fast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToRunAwayFromReallyFast): The scan feature refers to her as "Reaper of Souls".

[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill):
    - Mega-Death is an instant [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill) unless the party has Deathproof armor, or are under Zombie status. - Since Stone Glare is unblockable, Chac can instantly cause the afflicted character to suffer [Literally Shattered Lives](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiterallyShatteredLives) with any of its attacks. And Stone Glare is usually followed up by the [Herd-Hitting Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HerdHittingAttack) Heaven's Cataract.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): Her powers can make her sprout a gorgon head with skull hair and uses form this to battle.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): In X-2 she "returns" as one of the [Threshold Guardians](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThresholdGuardians) of the Via Infinito [Bonus Dungeon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BonusDungeon), the basilisk-like Chac.

[Our Ghosts Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurGhostsAreDifferent): After her defeat of Sin, she remained in the Zanarkand ruins as an Unsent to pass on knowledge of the Final Summoning to later summoners.

[Power Makes Your Hair Grow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerMakesYourHairGrow): In a horrifying way as she's a [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) [Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss) that begins to show her true powers as soon as her previous forms are defeated. Her ultimate one is a gorgon-like head with hair that resembles human skulls.

[Prehensile Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrehensileHair): You know her one [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form? Yeah, that's really her hair. Meaning she's freaking riding her hair and kicking back while kicking your ass in her final form.
[Puzzle Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss): Beating her requires thinking carefully about the mechanics of how her attacks work and taking advantage of them.
[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): She'll exploit this against the party by casting Curaga on anyone who is under the zombie status.
[Scaled Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScaledUp): Her third form resembles a giant Medusa head.
[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): Yunalesca is fought through three stages of the same boss fight.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut):
    - Her [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) seems remarkably similar to the goddess statue boss of *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*. - In addition, her overall design was reused from the Amano artwork of the Cloud of Darkness from *[Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII)*. And her [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel), aside from resembling the [Goddess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI), also resembles how the Cloud of Darkness looked as the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) of *Final Fantasy III*.
[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): There's no throne, but rather, she spends the entirety of her third phase lying down seemingly leisurely on her back.

[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Her attacks inflict a boatload of them, and understanding how they interact with one another is [the key to defeating her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss).

[Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist): Genuinely believes that life is hopeless and Sin can never be permanently overcome.
QUOTE  **Yunalesca**: Sorrow cannot be abolished. It is meaningless to try.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): She's completely naked and barefoot except for some [tiny thongs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThongOfShielding) [and a scanty bikini top](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarelyThereSwimwear).

[Super-Empowering](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperEmpowering): Her role in a summoner's pilgrimage is to grant the guardian of a summoner the power to become a Fayth that is powerful enough to destroy Sin.

[Sure, Let's Go with That](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SureLetsGoWithThat): The Ultimania guide for *Final Fantasy X* reveals that the Church of Yevon was founded shortly after she defeated Sin for the first time and she didn't know anything about it until summoners and their guardians encountered her Unsent in Zanarkand and told her about it and its teachings. She played along since the Church's rules and philosophies aligned with her own personal ideals, but never truly believed in it, so despite being okay with it, she has no issues dispelling the myth if it suits her purposes.

[Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill): If you don't have at least one character who is either zombified or wearing armor with the "Deathproof" attribute in your party when she enters her third phase, she will promptly inflict one on you with the Mega Death spell.
[The Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUndead): She has remained as an Unsent in the ruins of Zanarkand for 1,000 years.
[Undead Barefooter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndeadBarefooter): One of the reasons why she doesn't wear shoes may be that being undead, she doesn't care about discomfort and injuries.

[Villains Never Lie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsNeverLie): An odd example; while she is the main person perpetuating the Yevon religion and the Summoner's Pilgrimage, which are entirely based on lies, once the party finally meets her she freely admits the entire truth of the plot to them even though being honest to the heroes directly causes them to rebel and fight her. As she never believed in the Church of Yevon, lying doesn't seem like something she feels is necessary.
[Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): She was enshrined as a saint by the founders of Yevon out of fear.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): It is suggested she genuinely believes that the never-ending cycle of sacrificing summoners and guardians is [Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil) so the people of Spira will have some (false) motivation to keep living. The issue is that she's so obsessed with said cycle, that she refuses to let anyone go if they will not perform the Final Summoning, and has done nothing to discourage the Summoner Pilgrimage.
[Alliterative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlliterativeName): **Y**u **Y**evon.

[Almighty Idiot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlmightyIdiot): At the end of *X* you defeat Braska's Final Aeon Jecht, forcing Yu Yevon out of it. With no new Final Aeon to possess, he takes over the Aeons Yuna formed pacts with. One by one the party kills them all until he is left with nothing else to possess, leaving behind only the parasite creature you face as the final boss. That is all that is left of Yu Yevon, who "now exists only to summon." Nothing remains of the old Yu Yevon; it has no personality, thoughts or feelings, it's just a husk that lives only to destroy. It is "neither good or evil."
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He honestly doesn't know what he's doing anymore. Whether or not he's self-aware or even sentient isn't clear.
[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): Whatever intentions he had creating Sin, in the present era he is nothing more than a mindless force of destruction.

tropeName: Better to Die than Be Killed
tropeNotes: [Better to Die than Be Killed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BetterToDieThanBeKilled): When it became clear he would lose the war, Yu Yevon convinced the survivors to become Fayth for a mass summoning which would preserve their city for eternity.

[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): Shares this role with Seymour, as [the mastermind behind the creation of Sin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheCurtain); however, he is still the bigger threat. He stopped the Zanarkand-Bevelle War using Sin and consequently created a religion named after him that preaches false hope for the Spirans that ruled the world for the next 1000 years. Also possesses a summoner's Final Aeon to become a new Sin, caused numerous indirect [casualties for nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice), and trapped millions of Zanarkand souls to become Fayth.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): The Ultimania speculates that he may have conspired with Yunalesca to use the creation of Sin and the Final Summoning to establish what became the pilgrimage and the Yevonite faith. This way, he keeps summoning Dream Zanarkand while maintaining Spira's [Medieval Stasis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MedievalStasis).

[Death of Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathOfPersonality): Yu Yevon created Sin and directed it using his own disembodied spirit to protect Dream Zanarkand. However, after centuries of repeating the same mission and absorbing new Aeons, Yevon's mind slowly decayed until all he could think of was his mission. By the time the party confronts him, Yu Yevon the man had effectively ceased to exist long ago. All that was left was a mindless machine programmed to follow its former self's last wishes, but so simplistic and uncreative that it could only follow for most rudimentary versions of it.

[Demiurge Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemiurgeArchetype): He was once a human summoner who ruled the city-state of Zanarkand and destroyed himself in a war with Bevelle. Becoming a strange bug-like creature, he creates a false world, Dream Zanarkland, trapping the survivors inside, and becomes the god of the Church of Yevon, a religion which he uses to keep the rest of Spira in a [Medieval Stasis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MedievalStasis), keeping his followers in line by regularly attacking them with his literal [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon), Sin, and demanding pilgrimages that are essentially [Human Sacrifices](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanSacrifice). Like the Demiurge, Yevon rules over a false world and will do everything in his power to keep his subjects trapped within.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): He possesses the Final Aeon that defeats Sin and turns it into a new monster. In the final battle, he settles on possessing Yuna's "lesser" Aeons until he has nowhere left to hide. This ability is also why the Final Summoning is known to be fatal for the summoner. It's believed by the people of Spira that the Final Summoning is what kills the summoner, a lie perpetuated by his daughter Yunalesca never mentioning him. The reality is that his possession of the Final Aeon severs its connection to its Summoner, killing them in the process.
[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): He convinced all of his people to turn into Fayth and began summoning Sin because the war with Bevelle seemed hopeless.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Actually, he did *not* ban the machinery used for Blitzball - he may be intent on keeping Spira in a [Medieval Stasis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MedievalStasis), but he's not evil enough to ban machinery used solely for entertainment and sports. (And for attentive viewers, this will be the first major hint that the Yevonite "ban" on technology seems comparatively arbitrary.)
[Evil Luddite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLuddite): The purpose of Sin is to keep Spira frozen in a pre-industrial dark age.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Technically, though it's impossible to lose without hitting yourself with Stone status.

[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): Justified. He has an extensive background and possessed an identity at one point, but because of his actions prior to the game, he has become a blank slate. Just what he was like is never revealed, which has resulted in a couple of different character interpretations.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): The two Yu Pagodas from the Final Aeon fight carry over to the Yu Yevon possessing Aeons fight and then Yu Yevon itself.

[The Fundamentalist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFundamentalist): From what little we know about him, he was a pretty zealous leader, considering that he condemned all of Zanarkand's citizens to become Fayths and ground technological progress to a halt for over a thousand years.
[Giant Eye of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantEyeOfDoom): Yevon's symbol is watching you. *Always*. The eye is, for all intents and purposes, the final boss of the game.

[God Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsEvil): He's a summoner, but is revered as a god by the people of Spira, and has the power to back it up. At the time of the game, he is not aware of his actions and is said to be "neither good nor evil," but nevertheless acts as a destructive force.
[Gone Horribly Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyWrong): The process of summoning the Dream Zanarkand *and* Sin worked as intended but completely overwrote Yu Yevon's mind.
[Gravity Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GravityMaster): When Yu Yevon is finally seen after all the Aeons have been destroyed, his only attack is the Gravija spell Sin's external cores used earlier.

tropeName: He Who Must Not Be Seen
tropeNotes: [He Who Must Not Be Seen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoMustNotBeSeen): Although we *do* see him for the final battle, it is only in his parasitic form.
[Hidden Elf Village](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenElfVillage): His entire purpose now that his mind has collapsed is to create Sin to *enforce* this on Dream Zanarkand.

[Hidden Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenVillain): His name is not dropped until the third act of the game, and he does not even make an appearance until the final battle. Even worse, his human form is never seen. Despite this, his influence can be felt throughout the entire game through the Yevon religion.

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): He essentially damned the world for over a millennium to keep some semblance of his beloved city. Not only did he create Sin to "protect" Dream Zanarkand by keeping Spira in the dark ages, the dream is maintained by his enslaved citizens. Bahamut implies that this leaves the people in an [And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream) situation, constantly dreaming and unable to wake up.

[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): If the speculation that he conspired with Yunalesca to create what would become the pilgrimage and the Yevonite faith is true, then Yu Yevon was likely very cynical that the people of Spira could govern themselves or aspire to anything better. In his view, the lies and manipulation would be necessary to keep Spira going.

[Load-Bearing Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingBoss): Sin dissipates into pyreflies after Yu Yevon is defeated. Since Sin [itself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WombLevel) serves as the final dungeon, the heroes would have fallen from a thousand feet in the air if it weren't for the *Fahrenheit*. Afterwards, the Fayth are allowed to stop "dreaming" and journey to the afterlife, and the Dream Zanarkand fades away along with Tidus.

[Obliviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObliviouslyEvil): Because his sense of self has been destroyed, he has *absolutely* no idea of all the death and destruction he's causing during the game. However, he may have been evil prior to his mind wipe.

[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): Yu Yevon gave his summon very vague orders, but it's unknown if his intention was to destroy his city. However, he conveniently created Sin as an "armor" for himself. He kept a few survivors of the war alive, because without them, Sin would just be a normal Aeon. Those followers were turned into Fayth from which he could draw power to maintain "Zanarkand" as he destroyed other cities.
[The Paragon Always Rebels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels): Said to have been a "peerless" summoner.

[Person of Mass Destruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonOfMassDestruction): Created Sin, which has caused mass death, destruction, and terror to Spira for 1000 years. He continues to revive Sin whenever it is killed with the Final Aeon. The sheer magnitude of his summoning abilities means that he is likely the most powerful person to have ever inhabited Spira.
[Post-Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PostFinalBoss): The fight against him is literally set up in such a way that you cannot lose to him without intentionally trying to.

[Prefers the Illusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrefersTheIllusion): Faced with the destruction of his beloved Zanarkand, Yu Yevon chose not to build something new, but remake the city in a shared dream so he and all his people could spend centuries in denial.
[Puppeteer Parasite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppeteerParasite): At this point, he's just a fiend who jumps from one Aeon to another to keep Sin alive.
[The Remnant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRemnant): He and his daughter are the last 'living' survivors of the real Zanarkand, if you can call them that.
[Rule of Symbolism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfSymbolism): His current form is quite appropriately, a giant parasite.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): Technically, only the first encounter with Yu Yevon while possessing Jecht is a do-or-die boss fight (it alone has two stages), but then the game forces the team to kill each and every Aeon before they can kill Yu Yevon itself.
[Silent Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilentAntagonist): He has not a single line of dialogue in the entire game.
[Squashed Flat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquashedFlat): When Yu Yevon is defeated, his Yu Pagoda stones turn and combine with him in the middle, squashing him before they disintegrate.
[Undeath Always Ends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndeathAlwaysEnds): Once Jecht is defeated, Yu Yevon attempts to take control of Yuna's other Aeons, then dies once he runs out of vessels to inhabit.

[Utopia Justifies the Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtopiaJustifiesTheMeans): Dream Zanarkand is just that: an ideal city born from the Fayth's dreams. It's a strange representation of reality. In the Dream, things don't necessarily work the same way as they did in the real Zanarkand. Yu Yevon's end goal was to create an eternal city without conflict; Zanarkand would have lost the war to Bevelle had he not done so. Dream Zanarkand is a mirror of the city during the height of its power. It has all elements of conflict and war removed from it, basically a utopia. Hence why summoners are not a thing there, because they would have been without purpose. (Aeons are essentially tools of War.) The fayth only appear to have summoned the good bits of the city from their memory; the fun and the nightlife, not the politics.

[Vicious Cycle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViciousCycle): He's the reason killing Sin is one. First, a Summoner kills Sin with their Final Aeon, then Yu Yevon possesses the Final Aeon which kills the Summoner in the process and retreats to regrow the shell of Sin, repeat for eternity.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): This creature's existence is a spoiler for *FFX*.

[Was Once a Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasOnceAMan): But is now a floating tick...[thingy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuffySpeak), and the "brain" of Sin. His original human form is never depicted in-game.

[Written by the Winners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrittenByTheWinners): He became the leader of Zanarkand and led them in the Machina War against Bevelle a thousand years ago; ironic in light of later events.

[Zero-Effort Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroEffortBoss): Just as Maester Mika implied, he's helpless without his armor or any Aeons to flee inside of. The only way to lose is to petrify your own characters, but you'd have to do that on purpose.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): Shuyin's soul was trapped as an Unsent in the Den of Woe, and he was forced to relive the image of his lover's death every day for one thousand years.
[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): Especially when YRP run into him in the Den of Woe; this guy has lost all reasoning and has become quite maniacal.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Of *X-2*.

[Body Surf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodySurf): Two years before the game starts, he possessed Nooj, which caused him to fire on his friends (hence their breakup). Shuyin then lays dormant for a few years, until Nooj, Baralai, and Gippal meet up again, their bad blood with each other reawakening him and forcing him to jump to Baralai.

[Being Tortured Makes You Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeingTorturedMakesYouEvil): [His torture?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath) He was subjected to [watching](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedToWatch) his one true love be callously killed, in a loop, for ***one thousand years***. This [pushed him even further over the edge than he already was](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) [from living through it the first time.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds)

[Cloning Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloningGambit): There are two versions of Shuyin present in the game: the one who is inhabiting Nooj, and the one who is haunting the Den of Woe. The question of which Shuyin is the 'real' one is academic, since both are trying to kill you.
[Enemy Without](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyWithout): The real Shuyin died in the depths of Bevelle. A raw deal, sure, but his hate and resentment have taken on their own shape.
[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): In the Den of Woe.

[Evil Twin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin): He is Tidus in every aspect; attack animations, critical HP animation, and his special attack is Tidus' Blitz Ace Overdrive, albeit renamed to Terror of Zanarkand. Same dedication, same motivation, but where Tidus was willing to die to protect Yuna, Shuyin got both Lenne and himself killed.

[False Camera Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalseCameraEffects): In the Den of Woe sequence, the camera sometimes switches to Shuyin's perspective, and those shots have a static filter over them like a movie sphere. It's meant to reinforce that the Shuyin we're dealing with is a 'recording', not the real person.

[Fighting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingAShadow): Contrary to expectation, "Shuyin" is a ghost materialized by the original's hate. In the Den of Woe, it's implied that the Shuyin that the heroes are fighting is not even the same one fought aboard Vegnagun, but rather another copy created by the pyrefly-filled cave.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): He is your last opponent in *X-2*.

[Final Solution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalSolution): Vegnagun can blow up the entire world. Since it regards everything as an enemy, it will do exactly that. So not only would it destroy Sin, it would kill everybody, hence why it was mothballed and locked underneath Bevelle. Shuyin believes this the only way to bring peace to Spira.

[Glamour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Glamour): As Shuyin is embracing Yuna, a warning from an unexpected source shakes her out of trance. "Open your eyes!", yells Nooj. Yuna recoils from Shuyin, who turns out to be Baralai on disguise. Shuyin/Baralai mentions "The end is not far now", before generating a portal for himself and vanishing.

[Grand Theft Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftPrototype): In the present day, Shuyin is able to possess the bodies of the living and use them to commit evil deeds: specifically, he takes over Nooj then Baralai in an effort to carjack Vegnagun again.
[Knight of Cerebus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightOfCerebus): The moment he shows up is when the story starts to turn away from perky J-Pop concerts and really begins in earnest.
[Kubrick Stare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KubrickStare): Shuyin before being shot.
[Let's You and Him Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsYouAndHimFight): Shuyin seems to have this divide-and-conquer strategy down to an art.
[Living Bodysuit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingBodysuit): His ability.

[Love Makes You Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveMakesYouEvil): A thousand years ago, his girlfriend Lenne was a summoner fighting in the war between Bevelle and Zanarkand. Hoping to end the war before she died in battle, Shuyin snuck into Bevelle to use their machina superweapon Vegnagun against them. He was caught and summarily executed alongside Lenne, who had followed him there.

[Made of Phlebotinum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfPhlebotinum): The game doesn't even offer a token explanation as to why the pyreflies have suddenly turned hostile and are keeping a shadow of this guy alive. He's only running around killing people because his trauma from the war is being preserved. At most you get a couple lines in Shinra's glossary about how more research is needed on the pyrefly phenomenon. Spira still has no clue about how/why they exist or what they do.

[Meet the New Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeetTheNewBoss):
    - To Yu Yevon. He is not an unsent and cannot be dispatched unless he leaves his puppet body and takes physical form, which he finally does once he runs out of options. - Shuyin and Seymour have a lot in common, both being undead nihilists. The difference is that Seymour was corrupted over time; Shuyin was preserved at the height of his rage. However, they're both still vulnerable to emotional appeals. (From Anima and Lenne, respectively.)

[Motive Decay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveDecay): A tragically justified example. Before he became a ghost, he was just a desperate [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist), but a thousand years of being in the Den of Woe have reduced him into a screaming psychopath that only barely resembles the misguided but noble man he used to be.
[Motive Rant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveRant): Whoever this imposter in the meadow is, he's monologuing. Looks like we've found our villain.
[Moveset Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MovesetClone): he uses renamed versions of Tidus's Overdrives in the last fight of *X-2*.

tropeName: My Death Is Just the Beginning
tropeNotes: [My Death Is Just the Beginning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyDeathIsJustTheBeginning): Dying won't stop him from hijacking Vegnagun again, or punishing those he sees as the warmongers of Spira.

[Never Be Hurt Again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverBeHurtAgain): After a thousand years of psychological torture, all Shuyin can think of doing anymore is obliterating the people that put him through it.

[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): In another throwback to the 2D *Final Fantasy* games, Shuyin doesn't spare himself the same fate as his victims. He wants to "fade" away with Lenne after the destruction.
[Orcus on His Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone): Wasn't it nice of Shuyin to [delay activating Vegnagun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeYourTime) until the Gullwings got there?

[Perspective Flip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerspectiveFlip): The villain of the previous game was Sin, a giant, immortal sea-beast which turned out to be a parody of an Aeon with Sir Jecht at its heart. The final boss of the sequel is an anti-Sin weapon which is stolen by Shuyin. Shuyin strongly resembles Jecht's son Tidus, both in appearance and in his life choices, such as falling in love with a summoner. In a weird reversal, it is the ghost of Jecht, not Tidus, who cheers Yuna on.

[The Power of Hate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfHate):
    - His hatred and anger at the circumstances of his and Lenne's deaths were enough to keep him around as a ghost, a rarity in Spira. (It's not stated whether the real Shuyin was sent or not.) Not only that,but it gave him lots of powers that normal Unsent don't have. Seymour was a tough customer but even he couldn't possess the living, only the dead. - When Baralai threatens to shoot his meat-suit (Nooj), pyreflies emerge from Nooj and enter Baralai—and Baralai seems to have gotten the worse end of the deal. Shuyin quickly takes control and gloats that "the mind which hates" is "easier to break." It's hinted that Baralai left himself open for possession when he pulled a gun on Nooj.
[Sealed Evil in a Can](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan): His spirit was sealed in the Den of Woe. Even then, it still drove anyone who entered insane.
[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): He's controlling Vegnagun throughout the final battle, but isn't fought directly until Vegnagun (itself in multiple phases) is disabled.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): While his voice and appearance connect him to Tidus immediately, his abilities and personality are actually more closely related to Yu Yevon, the first game's end boss. A native of (real) Zanarkand, whose personality has been tortured away until he is more emotion and instinct than person. And he's [capable of possessing Aeons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeHorror), just like Yevon. If he didn't have access to a giant machina with a [Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun), he probably would have still been able to *create a new Sin.*
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): Upon revealing himself, he speaks with both his own voice and that of the person he's possessing, first Nooj and then Baralai.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Before he became an unsent, he just wanted to use Vegnagun to stop the war between his country and Bevelle before it killed his lover. After spending over a thousand years subject to [Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) from the Den of Woe, it's twisted into a belief that the only way to end war is to kill everyone.

[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds): The first time he tried to activate Vegnagun, it was to stop the war between Zanarkand and Bevelle because his lover, Lenne, was fighting on the front lines. That failed, but he remained an Unsent and was sealed in a cave off of Mushroom Rock Road. Said cave, by the way, was filled with pyreflies that recreated the pain and despair of his and Lenne’s deaths and forced him to relive it for a thousand years.

[A.I. Is a Crapshoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIIsACrapshoot): Why it was never used against Zanarkand or Sin; unlike other machina, it has a sentient mind of its own, but a childlike, impulsive one that never could tell between friend or foe; it would detect and attack any emotion that might put it in danger, and it would not protest any attempt to use its planet-killing potential against friendly forces.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Vegnagun itself has no malicious thoughts - Baralai even compares it to a frightened child. It's only when someone who has the will to inflict mass damage gains control over it that it becomes dangerous.

[Church Militant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChurchMilitant): Vegnagun was built by Bevelle, and many of its attacks have Latin names that refer to death or judgment.
    - The tail, for example, uses a swipe called Noli Me Tangere, or "Touch Me Not," said to be what Jesus told Mary Magdalene when she recognized him after his resurrection. - The Leg has an attack named Vita Brevis, meaning "life is short," which is taken from a quote by Hippocrates (of Hippocratic Oath fame). It also fires magic bullets, the most impressive of which is an eight-shot volley called Dies Irae, or "day of wrath," named after a hymn describing the day of judgment. - The core will bring its legs back to life if necessary, but otherwise charges up for Memento Mori, or "Remember you will die." The tusks will attack in unison with Pallida Mors, or "pale Death," which is how the Romans described their mythological personification of death. - The tusks will fire a laser named Lacrimosa, whose name is taken from the ending of the hymn "Dies Irae" ("Day of Wrath"). The head, meanwhile, will restore the tusks to life with Acta Est Fabula ("The play is over," supposedly the last words of Roman emperor Caesar Augustus) belch fire and statuses at you with Mors Cetra ("death is certain," typically followed by hora incetra, "the hour is uncertain"), suck everyone into a null dimension with Nemo Ante Morten Beatus ("no man can be called happy before his death") and shoots laser bullets at you with Odi Et Amo ("I hate and I love"), from a poem which equates love with the torment of crucifixion.

[Colossus Climb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColossusClimb): The first stop is the Tail, which isn't too threatening. All of its attacks ignore Defense, so it's better to bring in characters that are balanced toward offense, so they can outpace the Tail's damage. Once you win, the Tail collapses, opening the way forward. However, it seems like the Leblanc Syndicate is struggling to take out one of Vegnagun's main legs. The Leg itself can't do much against you; since you destroyed the Tail, Vegnagun is having trouble keeping its balance. But it will cast spells at you and occasionally take a swipe at the whole party. As before, winning moves the foot out of the way so you can continue. At the top, Vegnagun's head is taking a beating from Nooj and company... but giving as good as it gets. After you help them win the fight, Vegnagun collapses, and the Gullwings run up one of the legs to the cockpit.
[Contagious A.I.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContagiousAI): As Vegnagun absorbs more and more energy from the Farplane, the mossy terrain appears to be turning to metal.

[Contrasting Sequel Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelAntagonist): Sin was a magical monster built to be a suit of armor that became the center of all life in Spira. Vegnagun was a giant mechanical weapon that was hidden from the general population. Both have similar body shapes and are fought as a [Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss), with the final element including a [Non-Standard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardGameOver) where they fire a [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) of [Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun) proportions. In essence, the two are mirror opposites of each other, representing the duality of magic vs. machine.
[Cognizant Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CognizantLimbs): It's necessary to destroy its tail and one of its legs before moving on to its chest.
[Dreadful Dragonfly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DreadfulDragonfly): Resembles a giant mechanical dragonfly.
[Evil Is Not Well-Lit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotWellLit): It's dark inside Vegnagun's protective shell, which is trying to emulate the Cradle in Bevelle.

[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): Taken to the extreme with Shuyin. Vegnagun is a world-ending threat while Shuyin is just a pissed off spirit, yet Vegnagun is only an immediate threat because Shuyin is trying to use it.
[Humongous Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumongousMecha): It’s the second largest creature over the X games, second to only Sin.
[Instrumental Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstrumentalWeapon): It is controlled by an [organ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan) on its head.
[Killing Intent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillingIntent): Vegnagun can sense hostility and flees at the first sign of it.
[Ominous Pipe Organ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan): Bevelle installing a pipe organ, of all things, as the cockpit for their WMD.
[Knight of Cerebus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightOfCerebus): Just like Shuyin, the game loses a lot of its humor in almost every scene centered around it.
[Lost Superweapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostSuperweapon): It is the most powerful weapon left over from The Machina War, sealed underneath Bevelle.
[Mechanical Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalAbomination): Kind of obvious. It's an ancient monstrosity with a destructive ability that's only rivaled by Sin itself.

tropeName: My Death Is Just the Beginning
tropeNotes: [My Death Is Just the Beginning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyDeathIsJustTheBeginning): It is destroyed after the third battle with it. But then Shuyin just activates the giant cannon that is hidden in its body and is still very much operational.
[Non-Standard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardGameOver): Taking too long against the battle on its head gives time for Shuyin to fire off its giant cannon, wiping out the Calm Lands.
["Psycho" Strings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoStrings): Plays during the initial battles with its three components.
[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): It takes three battles to destroy it, and then a final battle to stop Shuyin from firing its main cannon.

[Spider-Sense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderSense): In Chapters 3 and 5, the Gullwings find Nooj standing in Vegnagun's resting place. The finale a tense stand-off: Nooj knows he can't even think too hard about destroying Vegnagun without spooking it. Last time he tried, it blasted a hole in the Cradle and fled underground. Meanwhile, Vegnagun is picking up on Nooj's anxiety; it stirs but does not react.

[Spikes of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikesOfVillainy): The shell covering Vegnagun's resting place is lined with spikes. It unfolds once it starts charging up the cannon. Vegnagun's metal hide and the cannon are also covered in spiked appendages.
[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): Just like with Sin, taking too long in the last battle ends with an automatic game over when Shuyin fires its cannon.

[Wham Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhamShot): How it is first revealed. We watch a cutscene where Shuyin walks through a shadowy room. The alarm goes on and we go from a close-up to a wide shot, giving us our first clear look at the gigantic machina.

[Badass Crew](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCrew): Seven people who each bring incredible skills to bear, enough so  (SPOILER) that they defeat a millenium old [Cosmic Horror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicHorror) and save the world.

[Beauty Equals Goodness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyEqualsGoodness): All of the human party members range from very pretty (Tidus, Yuna, Rikku) to rugged (Auron), to handsome and muscular (Wakka), to elegant (Lulu). All of them and Kimahri are heroic and kind (although Lulu, Kimahri, and Auron are more standoffish to varying degrees).

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): All of the group has this in spades:
    - Tidus goes from being a spoiled, childish jock (albeit a kind one) to a leader who is entirely devoted to Yuna as her fiercest advocate and protector. - Yuna grows from a demure, submissive young woman into an immensely mentally strong rebel who does right no matter the cost to her reputation or status. - Wakka develops from a racist zealot stemming from the loss of his brother into someone who embraces those of other faiths and walks of life, even (SPOILER) becoming a [Cool Big Bro](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolBigBro) to Rikku and naming his and Lulu's child "Vidina," which is Al Bhed for "Future." - Lulu is initially a frosty, untrusting individual to everyone. Her dealing with her traumas and failures allow her to outwardly develop into the outwardly kind, gentle woman she has always been internally. - Kimahri initially has great shame over his short stature as a Ronso and his broken horn - as he travels with the group, he realizes that he can still have pride despite it, (SPOILER) eventually defeating his tormentors and earning their respect. - Auron begins as the [Aloof Ally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofAlly) of the group due to his own deep emotional traumas from his previous pilgrimage - he eventually grows into a [Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad) for the group who is fiercely protective of them and their collective desire to save the world. - Rikku begins the story trying, in vain, to go the most extreme route of stopping summoners from their pilgrimages by kidnapping them entirely. She eventually learns that she can do right in different ways, becoming a Guardian and maturing significantly.

[Ragtag Bunch of Misfits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RagtagBunchOfMisfits): A fish out of water jock, the daughter of a legendary hero, their [Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute) with a dark past, a religious jock, an unfriendly goth woman, a cast-off Ronso, and an Al Bhed pirate - all of whom save the world.

[The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): When it comes to Blitzball the rest of the Aurochs talk up Captain Wakka and it's easy to see why. The Aurochs is easily the best player among them by quite a large margin in the story, and he's roughly equal to Tidus statistically in capability in the in game Blitzball minigame as well as better in most stats than any of the Aurochs in the mandatory game, which adverts [Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation) in that case.

[All Your Powers Combined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourPowersCombined): In blitzball, the secret Tech Aurochs' Spirit allows any active members of the original Besaid Aurochs to cumulate their SH stats and add them to Wakka's.
[Alphabetical Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlphabeticalThemeNaming): All the core members of the Besaid Aurochs, including Wakka himself, have double letters in their names.
[Anime Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimeHair): He sports an impossible charismatic pompadour.

[Anti-Air](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiAir): His main role within the party. He has exceptional starting Accuracy, making him the only character who can reliably hit flying enemies with his basic attack early on in the game. Other characters will catch up to him in this, though. Even after the others catch up, Wakka is still the only character who can strike far-away enemies (particularly Evrae and Sin) without the use of magic.
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): Towards both Yuna and Tidus, and later, Rikku.

[Big Fun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFun): Rikku jokes that he's putting on weight in *X-2*.
QUOTE "I'm gonna be a father soon! Gotta have a little more *presence*, you know?"

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal):
    - He spends most of the game as a devout Yevonite, until he discovers that they betray their own teachings by using the very machina they forbid. That, coupled with all of their lying, backstabbing, and assassination attempts on the party, really begins to sour Wakka on the church. By the end, he views them as "nothing but low-life tricksters" who are just getting in the way. - This is the crux of his rocky "relationship" with Beclem in *X-2*. Beclem arranged to be the Aurochs' new coach to see for himself why Chappu has nothing but praise for his older brother, and was intensely disappointed that Wakka didn't live up to Chappu's words.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): In the *Eternal Calm* cutscene and *X-2*, Wakka becomes the butt of a lot of fat jokes. A bit jarring in that he has the exact same character model throughout the series. The Besaid Aurochs also take turns making fun of him because he's such a [Panicky Expectant Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PanickyExpectantFather).

[Doesn't Like Guns](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesntLikeGuns): On a stricter sense. Stretches to most machina as well as the Al Bhed that continue to use them. Wakka opposes them both on principle, and because they prevented his younger brother Chappu from using their family's sword.
[Dumb Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbIsGood): One of the most dependable friends you'll ever meet, just as long as you don't talk politics or religion around him.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards):
    - He may be prejudiced against the Al Bhed, but he's nonetheless disgusted and furious when Seymour and the Guado invade and raze Home, the only Al Bhed settlement in Spira. Watching Rikku break down in tears pushes past any walls Wakka had left, and he joins in on the defense. Wakka might hate the Al Bhed, but mass slaughter is going *way* too far. QUOTE **Wakka**: [Damn those Guado!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsUnforgivable) What are they thinking?! - Wakka can be seen praying for those slain in Operation Mi'ihen, Crusaders and Al Bhed alike, despite the fact they turned against Yevon.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): His younger brother Chappu was killed during a Crusader operation while using an Al Bhed machina weapon; Wakka is quietly nursing a hatred of all three (the Crusaders, Al Bhed and machinery). He's forced to overcome his prejudices over the course of the game with Rikku's help. The fact that his son's name (Vidina) is Al Bhed for "future" shows that his emotional wounds have begun to heal. It veers into [Irrational Hatred](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IrrationalHatred) as the game goes on, and it becomes clear Wakka is so blinded by his anger at the Al Bhed, he doesn't even know Rikku was one until he finds out, and he is shocked to learn Yuna is half-Al Bhed, both of which get him to start questioning his racism and view of them.

[The Fundamentalist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFundamentalist): At the beginning, he's genuinely devoted to the Yevon religion, and willing to accept something as moral or immoral simply based on its doctrines. Discovering Yevon's sinister underbelly hits him much harder than the other characters.
[Gentle Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentleGiant): Like Kimahri he's one of the most physically imposing of the heroes, yet he's mostly a laid-back character.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): With Lulu as of *X-2*.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): He's willing, as along with Lulu, he's one of the two guardians who volunteers to become the Fayth for Yuna's Final Aeon, though she [refuses their offer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny).

[Hold Your Hippogriffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoldYourHippogriffs): He straight out insults Mika when the latter decides to just give up and disappear:
QUOTE **Wakka**: "Rotten son of a shoopuf!"
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): Big, tall, imposing, and relatively buff. Justified by him being focused on blitzball.
[I Know Madden Kombat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IKnowMaddenKombat): Since his weapon is a piece of sports equipment.

[Improbable Aiming Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAimingSkills): On the various [Boss Battles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle) onboard the [Global Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlobalAirship), or even throwing them just as powerfully *underwater*.
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): A blitzball. He can throw it hundreds of feet if he has to, and it always comes right back.

[Insane Troll Logic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsaneTrollLogic): Traveling with Tidus makes him wonder if his brother Chappu could still be alive, since Tidus strongly resembles Chappu and had an encounter with Sin and survived it. However, Chappu's deaths wasn't a case of [Never Found the Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverFoundTheBody), they *did* find his body after his death, so this chain of reasoning makes no sense. Lulu calls him out on this early in the game when it's clear he's hoping Chappu is somehow still alive somewhere and trying to come up with an explanation of how without much success.

[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): He strikes a contrast with Tidus because they are both bliztball-playing guardians but stand on opposite sides of Yevon (devotion and disrespect) and use opposite sides of attacks (ball and sword).

[Legendary Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegendaryWeapon): Wakka's [World Champion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) actually has a story behind it: it originally belonged to a previous High Summoner (and blitzball legend), Ohalland.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): The [Slot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BettingMiniGame) skills, which are divided into [Element Reels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers), [Attack Reels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDakka), [Status Reels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects), and [Aurochs Reels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StuffBlowingUp).
[Locked Out of the Loop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedOutOfTheLoop): About Yuna's heritage, and later about Rikku's identity as an Al Bhed.

[Long-Range Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongRangeFighter): His specialty, allowing him to easily hit aerial foes. He's got the best Accuracy and the second-best Strength (behind Auron). However, Wakka Speed and Evasion are both pretty bad.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): The Expert Sphere Grid allows him to sneak into Lulu's portion of the grid more easily and learn some of her spells, and he's given a substantial buff in his Magic stat in his own portion, which allows him to use said spells to almost as good an effect as she can.

[Mage Marksman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageMarksman): Wakka's primary ability is powerful ranged attacks and debuffs, but he also has minor magical skills for [Life Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDrain) and [Mana Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManaDrain) purposes.

[Megaton Punch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MegatonPunch): Lays one into Luzzu after being told that Luzzu was the one who convinced Chappu to enlist as a Crusader. And Luzzu should be lucky that's all he got; were it not for Tidus holding back Wakka, it would have been much worse, seeing as how Wakka was reduced to [Angrish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Angrish) and giving Luzzu a [Death Glare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathGlare).

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): He's got the best Accuracy, can improve Accuracy even further with the Aim ability, has the second-best Strength (behind Auron), and abilities that cause [Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects) while dealing damage. However, Wakka's Speed and Evasion are (respectively) the second-lowest and the absolute lowest.
[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): For most of Tidus' early time with the party, until the role is taken over by Lulu.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): He starts off hating the Al Bhed. Then he sees that they are good, hard-working people who end up being murdered left and right by Yevon, the religion he devoted himself to. Then to make matters worse, he realizes that the girl he considers a little sister is part of the people he's treated so horribly. He ends up apologizing, but that is AFTER he takes some time to (justifiably) let the shock set in and reflect on the news.

[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Despite his prejudice against the Al Bhed, he's a fun-loving [Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy) overall, and eventually overcomes said prejudice.

[Open Mouth, Insert Foot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OpenMouthInsertFoot): His blind religious devotion often puts him at odds with the events happening around him, and his attempts to cheer up Rikku and her family after the destruction of Home earn him nothing but mean looks and [a nasty scolding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero). Even he realizes how stupid he was for saying so.

[Panicky Expectant Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PanickyExpectantFather): Downplayed, but Lulu did say that Wakka is being really hard on himself the whole time. Most of the Besaid arc in *X-2* is Wakka coming to terms with becoming a good father.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Towards Yuna, of course. He took a fatherly role towards her before he became a father himself.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): To Chappu and Yuna. The former is his younger brother, and he is a Guardian to the latter. Chappu even lampshades it in a sphere in *X-2*, telling Wakka to "stop with the surrogate parent act" and just be his brother.
[Perma-Stubble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermaStubble): Wakka always has a fine layer of stubble over his chin and jawline, but never any actual facial hair.

[Politically Incorrect Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectHero): He's very overtly racist towards Al Bhed for a good portion for the story despite otherwise being a jovial and friendly [Gentle Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentleGiant). He later learns to overcome his prejudice and become a better person.

[Power-Up Letdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerupLetdown): Two of the three unlockable Reels, Status and Aurochs (the latter of which is supposed to be Wakka's ultimate [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak)), really pale in comparison to Attack Reels, which far surpasses Tidus' Blitz Ace and just behind Anima's Oblivion and Mindy's Passado as one of the most devastating attacks in terms of raw damage in the game.

[Promotion to Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotionToParent): Presumably happened with him and Chappu (although to hear him talk, Chappu was something of [The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce)), and to a lesser extent, he and Lulu looked after a young Yuna. Chappu complains a little about Wakka acting like a surrogate parent in one sphere shown in *X-2*.

[Quest Giver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuestGiver): Wakka gives the Gullwings one of their very first quests: finding a lost recording of Chappu from before he left the island. The Gullwings wind up uncovering an unrelated sphere which puts them on another track, but the Chappu sphere is eventually found late in the game.

[Real Men Love Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenLoveJesus): He's so passionately devoted to his faith that it causes problems later in the game. Admittedly, its implied he turned to Yevon after losing his parents at a young age, and doubled down when Chappu died. In the beginning, he is easily the most devout of all eight playable characters, *including Seymour, who is one of the leaders of the religion in question*. It takes the revelation of Rikku and Yuna's Al Bhed heritage, a collective telling off of him by her and the others, the destruction of Home, the revelation of Yevon's deep corruption, multiple assassination attempts on the party, and finally, the truth that Sin can never be destroyed by the Final Aeon for him to *finally* wise up for good.
[Religious Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousBruiser): The most devout follower of Yevon in the party, and one of the physically strongest.

[Second Place Is for Winners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecondPlaceIsForWinners): He pledges to retire after their final game against the esteemed Luca Goers, which the player has the opportunity to help him win. It turns out to be a very difficult match. Even if he loses, however, Wakka leaves the pool with a contented smile on his face.

[Shipping Torpedo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShippingTorpedo): Early in the game, he asks Tidus if Yuna's cute. If the player makes Tidus agree with Wakka's statement, Wakka immediately adds "not to get any ideas".

[Skewed Priorities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkewedPriorities): Discussed. He used to be a guardian for another summoner, but Wakka was so focused on blitzball that he was "too into the game to be a good guardian". Wakka even admits he was glad when said summoner decided to quit on the Calm Lands.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): A very subtle example: befriending and recruiting Tidus to the Aurochs was the first step towards guiding Tidus down the path to join Yuna's pilgrimage and eventually destroy the entire system Wakka deeply believed in. His, "Since we've come this far, may as well go all the way." statement in the Besaid Cloister of Trials ends up having far more of an impact than he'd realize.

[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): His Sphere Grid path specialty are attacks that cause darkness, silence, and sleep. His ultimate ability is Triple Foul, which causes all three effects at once.
[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance): Vidina inherits his father's [Idiot Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotHair).

[Super Not-Drowning Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperNotDrowningSkills): He's a Blitzball player and he can fight underwater. The other Aurochs even compliment his swimming skills in NPC dialogue, saying that Wakka can do multiple laps underwater while holding his breath.
[Tall, Dark, and Handsome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome): At 6'2".
[Tempting Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TemptingFate): He warns Tidus not to flirt with Yuna, to which Tidus asks, "But what if she comes on to me?" Wakka tells him she would *never* do that.

[10-Minute Retirement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TenMinuteRetirement): After the tournament in Luca, he retires from Blitzball, but [can be re-recruited later in the game anyway](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation).

[Tragic Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicBigot): His [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) towards the Al Bhed stem largely from Chappu dying in combat against Sin while using forbidden Al Bhed machina weapons. Several characters who knew him before Chappu's death make a point that Wakka is wrong for his racism, but they want him to improve and grow past it.

[Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine): Following learning that Rikku is an Al Bhed, the chain of events Wakka is involved in uproot his entire reality and belief system, and by the end of it all he is clearly shaken. Unlike most examples of this trope, the changes this ultimately has on him are for the better.

[Underdogs Never Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderdogsNeverLose):
    - The Aurochs, despite not having won a game in over a decade, somehow manage to beat the Al Bhed Psyches in their qualifying match. To put this in perspective, the Psyches' goalie's catching stat is so high, it is *numerically impossible* for the low-level Aurochs to get past him in regular gameplay. [The team became highly motivated just to be up against a team other than the Goers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation) after losing to them in the first round for at least 3 years running (just look at how low their morale is when Tidus enters the locker room) and there's no doubt Wakka himself became even more determined after learning the Al Bhed had kidnapped Yuna. - Possibly averted in the following match which you actually play (and against the aforementioned Goers, no less). Though it's possible to win it with careful planning and some luck, chances are on your first try, you will lose. [Hard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle). And then the plot goes on.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Though Wakka had the right idea stopping Tidus from snooping around in Yuna's room while the group took a short break, it did prevent Tidus from finding the sphere in Yuna's possession that warned her of Seymour Guado's [true nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilAllAlong).
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): He has quite a noticeable one, ya? Likes to end his sentences with it all the time, ya?

[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): He is wearing a top, but it only covers his stomach and leaves his chest exposed save for a pair of suspenders. Partially justified by the fact he lives in a hot climate, but even among the ice and snow, he never puts a shirt on.

[You Remind Me of X](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouRemindMeOfX): Apart from Tidus' display of blitz skills, this is the reason Wakka immediately befriended him, and something that Lulu lambasted him for: that Tidus apparently looked like Wakka's dead brother (and Lulu's lover) Chappu.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Her magic is extremely powerful and will obliterate many foes, especially early on.
[Aloof Dark-Haired Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofDarkHairedGirl): Pale-skinned with very elaborately decorated black hair. She's seemingly cold and reserved with a no-nonsense attitude.
[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): She's the only character who doesn't have a hybrid class.

[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): Of the two previous summoners she guarded, one had a crisis of faith and abandoned the pilgrimage, and the other died without Lulu unable to protect her. Also, her boyfriend died trying to fight Sin. No wonder she's such an [Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IceQueen) at first.

[Buxom Beauty Standard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuxomBeautyStandard): Has a busty figure that is prominently displayed due to the [Impossibly-Low Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossiblyLowNeckline) in her outfit. One cutscene has Tidus using his binoculars to [stare at her chest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EatingTheEyeCandy) and Rikku has dialogue whese she confesses she  [envies Lulu's "maturity"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ACupAngst).

[Cool Big Sis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolBigSis): Yuna sees her as an older sister, and later, Rikku does as well, so much so that she wishes to learn magic. Rikku herself seems to fantasize about one day possessing Lulu's, ahem, [talent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnusualEuphemism). She also develops this relationship with Tidus over time, offering him pieces of advice regarding the world in a firm but caring way. On his part, Tidus feels comfortable enough with her to give her some dating advice in return, suggesting she move on from Chappu with Wakka.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): Early in the game, Lulu will be the heaviest hitter thanks to her magic, which is crucial in several boss fights. Late-game however, the tides start to turn, especially if/when the player completes Yuna's Sphere grid and moves her on to start learning Lulu's magic. Towards the endgame, the only way for Lulu to break the 9999 damage limit is by dodging two hundred *consecutive* lightning bolts in the painfully difficult and tedious Lightning Dodge game. Many players skip it entirely and relegate Lulu to a supporting role in favor of characters like Yuna who can break the damage limit with little difficulty. Her Overdrive will also see significantly less frequent use, particularly after she learns Doublecast and fully powers up her Onion Knight, which will allow her to spam Ultima without worrying about MP.

[Cynicism Catalyst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CynicismCatalyst): Lulu is a no-nonsense black mage and a (repeatedly) failed guardian; she's still wracked with guilt over watching her first summoner die. She was in a relationship with Chappu when he signed up for a foolhardy Crusader mission to keep her safe. Sin crushed him and left his body on the Djose shore. Her personal losses left Lulu very cold, yet fiercely-protective of her friends.

[Cultural Cringe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalCringe): She has none of the Besaid verbal tics or accent, which Wakka and some NPCs, including the Aurochs, have. Also, randomly at the start of a battle with her and Yuna in the formation, Yuna may imitate Wakka's voice and say "Lots of fiends here, ya?" to which Lulu will reply with a shudder and by saying "[Don't talk like that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StopBeingStereotypical)."

[Dance Battler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DanceBattler): Of a sort. Lulu's Evasion is staggeringly high for most of the game, and equipping her with the Dancer overdrive mode will max out her bar in very little time.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): Lulu's cold demeanor and heavily sexualized outfit would make her a perfect evil sorceress in any other work, but it turns out that she's actually quite warm underneath it all — she's just carrying a heavy burden of pain and guilt.

[Defrosting Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceQueen):
    - Towards Tidus as she gets to know him and sees that he's an asset to their pilgrimage and not a liability. Her first sign of defrosting is when she drops her icy persona and shows genuine concern for Tidus' well-being after the aftermath of Operation Mi'ihen. She also goes from telling Tidus not to romantically pursue Yuna to personally requesting that he stay with her after Sin has been defeated. - In the sequel, Her VA is noticeably less gruff. She is no longer haunted by the deaths of her summoner or Wakka's brother.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): *Heavy* on the deadpan, light on the snark. In fact, the creators of *X-2* said that they didn't include Lulu as the third playable character because her no-nonsense attitude would have completely shut down Yuna and Rikku's playful banter. Lulu herself acknowledges this when Yuna returns to Besaid.

[Eerie Pale-Skinned Brunette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EeriePaleSkinnedBrunette): Yet another way in which she stands out as a native on Besaid Island. Also one of the most intimidating party members until you get to know her better.

[Face Palm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FacePalm): This is practically one of her [Character Tics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterTics), since it happens almost every time she sees Tidus and Wakka are not acting their age.

[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight): She has been a guardian to two summoners before Yuna, one of them, Lady Ginnem, did not survive the journey to Zanarkand due to Lulu failing to protect them in the Cavern of the Stolen Fayth, something Lulu feels deeply guilty of.
[Girls Love Stuffed Animals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlsLoveStuffedAnimals): Especially when they animate and attack enemies for her. They are literally her weapon class.

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): As a Black Mage, she's capable of devastating levels of pain to enemies. She's got good Evasion and Speed, too. However, her Strength and Defense are both sub-par, meaning she can't take what she dishes out.

[Goth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Goth): While there's no evidence of a goth subculture in Spira outside of her, it's obvious where the real-world inspiration for her character design came from. Real world Goth culture owes a lot to the influence of *memento mori*, a Romantic-era art movement that emphasized the inevitability of death. It's not inconceivable that in a world like Spira, locked as it is in a spiral of death, there would be people who embraced that philosophy wholeheartedly.
[Goth Girls Know Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GothGirlsKnowMagic): Her fashion is obviously inspired by goth culture, and she learns many black magic spells.

[Hair-Trigger Temper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairTriggerTemper): Wakka describes her as having a short fuse before she's introduced, but her anger tends to fall under [Tranquil Fury](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranquilFury) instead of being big and loud due to her cool and stoic personality.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): With Wakka as of *X-2*.

[Heartbroken Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartbrokenBadass): She was dating Chappu before he died fighting Sin. While she keeps a stoic facade due to her duty as a guardian, she's still grieving his death.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Like Wakka, she is willing to give her life so that Yuna can summon the Final Aeon, though Yuna [has other ideas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption).

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) has stated that her usage of dolls for combat is meant to show a hidden cuter side of her mature womanly character, which is hard to see on the surface.

[Hot Witch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotWitch): The character designers intended her look as a cross between an [Obeah vodoo priestess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obeah) and a fashion model, throwing in plenty of [Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fanservice) for good measure.

[I Let Gwen Stacy Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILetGwenStacyDie): Her fierce attachment to Yuna is partially a product of the guilt she feels over the death of one of the previous summoners she guarded. She has an opportunity to atone for this failure should the party decide to go into the Cavern of the Stolen Fayth.
[Iconic Outfit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IconicOutfit): Lulu's [sultry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice) [attire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotWitch) is very popular among fans.

[Impossibly Cool Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossiblyCoolClothes): She wears a fancy black dress with a fur-tripped collar and a [skirt made entirely out of belts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyBelts). This is the outfit she wears for the *entirety* of the duology. Not exactly designed for all-terrain or all-weather, but she manages to travel the world without difficulty. Even her hairdo is irresponsibly cool: a combination of beaded braids, cornrows, and decorative Kanzashi.
