[Beware the Nice Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheNiceOnes): Paine says as much. Leblanc's goons expect he'll be useless without an escort to do the fighting for him. Needless to say, in the boss battle he doesn't need them.
[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): See [Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon).
[Carry a Big Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarryABigStick): He has a staff-spinning attack which only hits targets close to him.
[Chromatic Arrangement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChromaticArrangement): The green to Nooj's red and Gippal's blue.

[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): The subject of Nooj's betrayal is clearly this for him. The tone Baralai's voice takes during his talk with Seymour after the Crimson Squad massacre as well as the fact that Shuyin possesses Baralai almost immediately after he confronts Nooj in the Bevelle Underground makes it clear that any thought of that incident and the events leading up to it is the point at which he is mentally and emotionally weakest.

[Distressed Dude](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistressedDude): In the second half of the game, Baralai confronts the other Crimson Squad survivors in Vegnagun's Cradle; his body is taken over by Shuyin and dragged to the Farplane to recover Vegnagun. Nooj and Gippal give chase out of a sense of camaraderie.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): The Id in the trio consisting of him, Nooj, and Gippal.
[Grand Theft Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftMe): By Shuyin, after he [hops from Nooj.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodySurf)

[Heartfelt Apology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartfeltApology): At the end of X-2,  (SPOILER)  he, Nooj and Gippal apologize to the people of Spira for almost dragging them into a war over their own hang-ups.

[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): A recurring character trait. He's pleasant and sociable in regular conversation. Once in battle or sufficiently angered, the dude's a regular berserker for all the yelling he does. For all the stoicism that he exudes whenever the Gullwings encounters him, he freaks out when he and Gippal meet with Nooj in the Bevelle Underground.
[Peace Conference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeaceConference): No matter which ending you receive, Baralai will bury the hatchet with the Youth League in public.
[Screaming Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScreamingWarrior): During the battles with him, he has no actual battle quotes, only furious yelling.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesIHaveConnections): was originally a member of the ill-fated Crimson Squad, and later sought refuge with Seymour Guado, thus explaining his inexorable rise. Seymour expunged his record so that nobody could tie him to the Youth League leader.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): He has this with Paine, as seen in the Crimson Spheres.

[Significant White Hair, Dark Skin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignificantWhiteHairDarkSkin): He has dark skin with silver hair despite being a fairly young human man. He turns out to lead one of the major political factions in Spira, and the game vaguely suggests his appearance is a sign of [White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart),  (SPOILER) but it ultimately turns out to be Nooj, who's possessed by the vengeful spirit of Shuyin .
[Telescoping Staff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TelescopingStaff): When you fight him, his main weapon is a battle staff that can extend for attacks.
[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): He's the most softspoken of the three leaders in Spira during FFX-2.

[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): Baralai has a few nasty tricks if you aren't prepared. Demi pierces Reflect, and Drill Shot lops off 75% of the target's max HP. It's a Blue Bullet attack which you can only learn from him.

[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): With Nooj, Gippal, and Paine. From the scene in the Bevelle Underground, it's easy to see that though Gippal, Paine, and Nooj seem to have moved on from the Crimson Massacre incident, Baralai definitely hasn't. Almost screamed word for word:
QUOTE  **Baralai:** WHY DID YOU SHOOT?! WHY DID YOU SHOOT GIPPAL AND ME?! WE WERE FRIENDS, AND YOU SHOT US IN THE BACK!! *ANSWER ME!*

[White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart): Subverted. He comes off as a rather suspicious figure with implications of the victorious [Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream) kind when first introduced, and there's plenty of reason to think he's evil, given that he fights the party in order to protect yet another one of Bevelle's dark secrets, and his sphere also reveals that after the Crimson Squad fiasco, he sought help from *Seymour* of all people. However, later on, it becomes clear that Shuyin-possessed *Nooj* is the actual villain, and Baralai doesn't get around to his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn) until after Shuyin swipes his body. The ending makes it pretty clear that he's one of the good guys, working for the betterment of Spira.
    - In essence, he's basically a character inversion of Seymour. In the backstory, he mysteriously rises to leadership of a reformed New Yevon despite never even appearing in the first game, and there's a couple hints that an [Arranged Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArrangedMarriage) was attempted between himself and Yuna. The developers clearly tried to paint an image of a Seymour expy early on, only to subvert it as he was [Good All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodAllAlong). Then double-subverted when Shuyin body hops over from Nooj, meaning that Shuyin is using Baralai's body to control Vegnagun.
[Artificial Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialLimbs): Two of them.

[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): Once he is free of Shuyin's influence, Nooj wastes no time telling Paine to stay away before Shuyin, now in Baralai's body, ever has the chance to attack her. And then he spends the rest of the game with Gippal trying to save Baralai from Shuyin.
[Chromatic Arrangement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChromaticArrangement): Wears a lot of red to contrast with Gippal's blue and Baralai's green.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker):
QUOTE **Paine**: You were ready to give up back there. Ready to die. 
**Nooj**: Very perceptive. You'll be a legend among recorders.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): As Shuyin explains, this made him an easy target for possession at the time of the Crimson Massacre. Nooj's sphere alludes this to being part man and part machine and just being depressed over the loss of his own limbs.

[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): By Gippal, who doesn't seem to hold any grudge towards Nooj for the shot taken at him (and Gippal had a clear view that Nooj was the one that did it), and Paine, who explains to Yuna and Rikku that she saw Nooj's actions as an accident resulting from the strange pyreflies from the Den of Woe (admittedly, it turns out that [it wasn't of his own free will](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftMe), but neither of them knew that). Baralai, however, averts this full-stop.
[Fixed Damage Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FixedDamageAttack): His [Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove) in the Fiend Arena, Lightfall, deals 5,000 damage to the entire party.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): The Superego of the trio consisting of him, Baralai, and Gippal.

[Gollum Made Me Do It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GollumMadeMeDoIt): He is one of four survivors of the Den of Woe incident: Unbeknownst to him, he is still carrying the malevolent entity known as Shuyin, who promptly hijacks Baralai when the pair meet again beneath Bevelle.

[Grand Theft Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftMe): It's hard to tell how much of Nooj's actions were subconsciously driven by Shuyin following his possession in the Den of Woe two years prior, but it's clear that Shuyin is the one that shot Baralai, Gippal, and Paine and was also the one that surfaced in the Bevelle Underground.
[Handicapped Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandicappedBadass): Presumably, he can fight well enough to support the Gullwings in the final battle.

[Heartfelt Apology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartfeltApology): At the end of X-2,  (SPOILER)  he, Baralai and Gippal apologize to the people of Spira for almost dragging them into a war over their own hang-ups.
[Improbable Hairstyle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableHairstyle): What is it with this series and antigravity hair?

tropeName: No Guy Wants to Be Chased
tropeNotes: [No Guy Wants to Be Chased](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoGuyWantsToBeChased): He is deeply indebted to the LeBlanc Syndicate, but he doesn't return their leader's romantic affections.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): If the player enters the Den of Woe, he can be battled.

[Rebel Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelLeader): As captain of the Youth League, which is essentially filled with the younger generation of Spira that, on top of being relatively inexperienced, does not understand that not everything can be solved with violence.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Nooj the Undying.
[Rummage Sale Reject](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RummageSaleReject): His outfit is nothing short of ridiculous.

[Supporting Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingLeader): He is later spotted in the Bevelle Underground, where he witnesses Shyuin possessing Baralai. When Yuna gets knocked into one of the holes linking Spira with the Farplane, she momentarily spots Nooj and Gippal, who tell her to "take care of things topside." We later find out that Nooj and Gippal (along with the LeBlanc Syndicate) have chased Shuyin into the Farplane to rescue their friend. When their combined efforts fail to faze Vegnagun, the Gullwings join the fight.
[Survivor's Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorsGuilt): Nooj lost a quarter of his body in a battle with Sin and replaced his lost limbs with machina, which left him feeling fatalistic.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): We learn he is famous enough to be notorious, and in Bevelle we start to get the first signs of his self-destructive tendencies. After his brush with Sin (i.e. death) he is unable to rest until he meets a warrior's end. There's echoes of Auron in there. They both wear red, as well.
[Tall, Dark, and Handsome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome): LeBlanc certainly thinks so.

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): At the end of the game, Nooj journeys ahead of the party and straps a bomb to himself so he can be re-possessed by Shuyin and kill them both. Yuna is appalled by his plan and manages to talk him out of it.

[Throwing Off the Disability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowingOffTheDisability): Nooj discards the cane when he's under Shuyin's influence. Although Nooj has his artificial leg and limps slightly in flashbacks, he's seen without his cane at the Den of Woe. When Baralai draws a pistol on him beneath Bevelle, Nooj's body shimmers green for a moment and he drops his cane.
[Too Many Belts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyBelts): As usual for Nomura character designs. Nooj in particular is probably the worst offender by a long shot, even by Nomura's standards.
[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): With Baralai, Gippal, and Paine.

[BFG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFG): Here's a weird one: Gippal has an eight-barreled blunderbuss with a [rotary saw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainsawGood) mounted on it for close-quarters attacks. He's the only person a Gun Mage can learn the Mortar skill from.
[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): He might not seem like [The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy) but he's a genius when it comes to machines.
[The Charmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCharmer): Cocky and and cool enough to make even Rikku blush.

[Everyone Loves Blondes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneLovesBlondes): A male version. He's well-liked, the leader of an organization and Yuna definitely takes notice when he walks past. And his theme music is a guitar riff that basically tells us "this guy is cool".
[Eyepatch of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyepatchOfPower): He sported it two years ago, so it's unknown how he lost his eye. Unless it's just a fashion statement.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): The Ego in the trio consisting of him, Nooj and Baralai.
[Genki Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGuy): He tones it down when things get serious but he's quite the ray of sunshine.

[Heartfelt Apology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartfeltApology): At the end of X-2,  (SPOILER)  he, Nooj and Baralai apologize to the people of Spira for almost dragging them into a war over their own hang-ups.

[Implied Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpliedLoveInterest): For Rikku, by way of saying "[we made quite the couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident)". Rikku frequently denies that anything ever happened, but it's made clear across the game that she feels *something* for him.
[Improbable Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAge): He's the leader of the Machine Faction at only eighteen! Presumably his experience in the Crimson Squad helped give him some clout.

[Like Brother and Sister](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeBrotherAndSister): With Paine. It's subtle, but definitely there: Gippal is the only one that Paine bothers willingly showing her face in front of when YRP meets the various leaders of Spira for the first time.

[Maybe Ever After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaybeEverAfter): Rikku definitely shows some concern for him when Djose Temple is attacked. They're seen leaving the Farplane together, though both end the game with their respective friends rather than each other.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): If you go into the Den of Woe, he can be battled like Nooj.

[Remember the New Guy?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RememberTheNewGuy): He hated Sin and wanted to become a Crusader, but the Al Bhed weren't eligible; when he heard that the Crimson Squad were less discriminatory, Gippal leapt at the chance. He decided to lay low after Yevon tried to cover up the incident, and Paine plays it off as though they have never met. He is briefly seen conversing with Auron in a recording taken shortly before Home was destroyed in *X*.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Not only is he the head of the only faction that's not at odds with anyone else, but he's also the only leader who realizes that Yuna's done enough for Spira and that people need to learn to solve their own problems instead of running to the High Summoner every time there's trouble.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): He's got it with both Yuna and Rikku (more so with the latter, especially considering he seems to come on a bit too strong for Yuna's taste).
[Spiky Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikyHair): He's unique in the series that his hairstyle is actually possible to pull off in real life.
[Strange Minds Think Alike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrangeMindsThinkAlike): One of the Crimson Spheres shows that he called Paine "Dr P" as well; it's one of Rikku's nicknames for her.
[[Verb] This!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbThis): Gippal says "Dodge this!" when using Bullseye.
[War for Fun and Profit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarForFunAndProfit): The Machine Faction seem to imply that they are supplying weapons to both sides of the political conflict.
[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): With Baralai, Nooj and Paine.
[The Anti-Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAntiNihilist): She considers her life to have been a good one, although by objective standards it was tragically cut short.
[Anguished Declaration of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnguishedDeclarationOfLove): Sadly, Shuyin didn't hear it. Yuna's goal in the end is to help Lenne express her feelings to him.

[Contrived Coincidence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrivedCoincidence): She's a summoner who has a Zanarkand blitz player for a lover. The official stance on their connection to Tidus and Yuna are supposedly coincidental.
[Ghost in the Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GhostInTheMachine): Lenne's spirit still clings to Yuna's dressphere.
[Go Out with a Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoOutWithASmile): Before guards shot them dead, Lenne used her last moments to smile at Shuyin.
[Grand Theft Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftMe): She does *not* ask for permission when possessing Yuna's body. Yeah, she has good intentions most of the time, but...
[The Ingenue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheIngenue): Skilled in performing arts as well as the summoning arts of Zanarkand.

[I Should Have Been Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShouldHaveBeenBetter): She doesn't blame herself for Shuyin's crimes, but she wonders if things would have been different had she been honest about her feelings.
[I Wrote Our Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWroteOurStory): Her songs are very heavily based on her experiences in real life.
[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): She is this for Shuyin. Although he's dead as well, he's still lingering as an unsent.
[Manic Pixie Dream Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManicPixieDreamGirl): A non-romantic example. The first indication of her existence is when she possesses Yuna to help the girl relax and have fun.

[Nothing Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NothingPersonal): She doesn't hate the people of Bevelle (and actually becomes...friends? with Yuna, who was born there). She will rip them to bits with her aeons, but that's not the same thing.

[Patriotic Fervor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatrioticFervor): It's unclear whether Zanarkand was fighting back in self-defense, but either way, Lenne was entirely willing to fight on her hometown's behalf.
[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): Her dressphere outfit.

[Silent Treatment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilentTreatment): When Lenne and Shuyin had a bad fight over her role in the war, she refused to speak to him even as he stormed out. She deeply regrets this, not least because it meant she [Never Got to Say Goodbye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverGotToSayGoodbye).

[Silk Hiding Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilkHidingSteel): Though she looks frail and harmless, she was a summoner, which has been shown to be extremely difficult. What's more is that she fought on the front lines during the war between Zanarkand and Bevelle.
[Soul Jar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoulJar): The Songstress Dressphere is one of hers, though she's using it willingly and appears to be able to leave whenever she wants.
[Star-Crossed Lovers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarCrossedLovers): With Shuyin.
[True Blue Femininity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueBlueFemininity): Lenne's dress and Yuna's Songstress outfit is blue. Notable because it's the only Dressphere with plot significance.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Wants to [avenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Revenge) the death of his Ronso comrades because of Seymour's actions two years earlier, even though the Guado people had nothing to do with that massacre.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Wants to wipe out the Guado for Seymour's crimes. Even after Yuna determinately stops him, he will show rage at being unable to use his Ronso powers in battle.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He blindly hates the Guado for Seymour killing Maester Kelk, Biran, Yenke and other Ronso.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Garik can be recruited through the Creature Creator, even if the Chapter 5 events in Gagazet have yet to be played.

[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): After besting him in Chapter 3, if Yuna had spoken to the Ronso previously, and told Garik that the Ronso tribe shouldn't attack just for revenge, Garik will come to terms that his plan to kill the Guado was wrong. Otherwise, Garik still respectfully accepts Yuna's terms, but instead believing that he isn't strong enough to take the Guado down yet.

[Guilt-Free Extermination War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuiltFreeExterminationWar): Garik and his followers want to kill every last Guado in retribution for Seymour's massacre of the Ronso two years ago. If YRP don't convince him to let go of his hatred, he will slaughter every Guado man, woman and child in the Macalania Forest, extinguishing the Guado race for good.

[Religious Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousBruiser): He asks the spirit of Mount Gagazet for advice before embarking on his quest for revenge. What (he thinks?) the mountain says varies depending on whether Yuna has pacified the Ronso tribe, although he decides to attack regardless. In the optimal route, he admits that he knew Gagazet's silence was a rejection of his desire, and that he was foolish to defy its will.
[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): Kimahri delivers one of these to him.
[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): He underestimates both Yuna and Kimahri, mistaking their desire not to go to war as a weakness.
[Vengeance Feels Empty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VengeanceFeelsEmpty): If YRP don't convince him and he exterminates ths Guado, Garik will continue to feel unsatisfied despite the Guado being extinct.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Garik pretty much disappears after the Mount Gagazet story ends. He does end up as a playable character with Creature Creator in Chapter 5, but beyond that he is nowhere to be found.
[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): When Yuna defeats him in battle he agrees to swear off his revenge and follow Yuna's lead.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): After all the good Chappu spoke about Wakka, Beclem had been looking forward to meeting him for quite some time. Upon finally doing so, he is disappointed in how soft and weak he thinks the other man is, but eventually comes around.

[Consummate Professional](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConsummateProfessional): Despite his bad attitude and how he rubs Yuna and the others the wrong way, he *is* very good at his job and does everything he can to whip the Aurochs into shape.
[Defrosting Ice King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceKing): He eventually warms up to Wakka and the Aurochs, and before leaving the island he gives Yuna a sphere of Chappu to give to Wakka.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Beclem turns out to be a very talented blitzball player himself, and shows off his skills before departing the island. Additionally, when the Gullwings play against the Aurochs in a blitzball match he is on their team.

[Nay-Theist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NayTheist): He is very outspoken of his hatred for Yevon, and New Yevon by extension. But when he speaks against the Summoners, Yuna thinks he's taking it too far.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): When fiends start pouring out of the temple, his first reaction is to burn the whole thing down, prompting this reaction from Wakka and Yuna and the others. In return, Beclem gives one to Wakka when the latter suggests fighting all the fiends, and says that Wakka shouldn't be so reckless when he is about to become a father.
[Adventurer Archaeologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdventurerArchaeologist): Nhadala is a no-nonsense digger who leads the excavation efforts in the Sanubia Sands.
[Drives Like Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivesLikeCrazy): At one point when escaping from debt collectors, he hijacks their hover and crashes it into the trees to get away.
[Keet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Keet): Tobli is a highly excitable constant bundle of energy.
[Motor Mouth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotorMouth): Constantly chattering, even if  Yuna actually wanted to refuse his requests, it'd be difficult to get a word in edgewise.
[Record Producer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecordProducer): Tobli essentially acts as this for the Macalania Forest musicians, and later for Yuna herself.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): He often says "Yup-yup!" at the end of his sentences.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): He is an extremely strong-willed man who resists becoming a fiend and can take on and tame the strongest of the Weapon species with his bare hands—and win. He's a pretty fast opponent, made even speedier in the Creature Creator where you can recruit him.

[Dead All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadAllAlong): According to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), he was an unsent to begin with, but he posed as a priest to infiltrate the heart of Yevon.
[Ice-Cream Koan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IceCreamKoan): The apparent [Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming) of his basic attacks.
[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): An Unsent, that is, yet he remains in human form. All the bosses in Via Infinito answer to him.

[Principles Zealot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrinciplesZealot): He admits to the Gullwings that he destroyed his entire sphere collection, his rationale being that people must discard the past to face the future.
[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): After defeating him in Via Infinito, he can be captured through the Creature Creator.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): Even though there's a lengthy cutscene between them, the Gullwings fight Trema right after Paragon, with the party's condition carrying over between the two battles.

[Super Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperBoss): *The* most powerful enemy in vanilla *X-2*. (In the *International* versions, while still powerful, he's lost the spot of "ultimate challenge" to Major Numerus and Almighty Shinra).

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Trema remarks that without Sin, there was no unified enemy for the people of Spira, and so in turn they would turn their swords on each other. This pretty much is the Youth League as Lucil said in her speech at the end of Chapter 5.

[You ALL Look Familiar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouALLLookFamiliar): He uses the same model as the raggedy priest who introduces you to Yunalesca in the previous game, but they're probably not the same person.

[You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): Once Paragon tires, he looks over his shoulder and sees Trema, who takes a giant leap and *punches him across the room*. Paragon explodes under the fury of the old man's Repeating Fist.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): For the Bikanel storyline.

[Cognizant Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CognizantLimbs): Its two arms, Tawrich (right) and Zarich (left), are treated as separate targets. If the player takes care of them first, Angra Mainyu will just cast Full-Life on them.

[Dug Too Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DugTooDeep): The Machine Faction accidentally broke the seal on Angra Mainyu during their desert excavations. It starts running amuck on Bikanel Island until it attacks the Cactuar Nation and then attacks the Machine Faction's camp.

[Final Boss Preview](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBossPreview): If unlucky, the Gullwings can prematurely meet this monstrosity as early as Chapter 1. However, after enough time in battle it will just Eject the party.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): The fact that it commands snakes to assault the Cactuar Nation makes it seem like it is related to them, like a [King Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingMook) (and Angra Mainyu's outline does loosely evoke the design of X's snake Fiends). However, it is still a [Unique Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniqueEnemy), and it cannot be Oversouled by them.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): The option to whittle down its HP in earlier encounters prior to the actual fight in Chapter 5. This is reminiscent of the battles of both Deathguise of *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/FinalFantasyVI)* and Ultima Weapon of *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/FinalFantasyVII)*.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): A properly-prepared party will have no problems with facing it, however.

[Sealed Evil in a Can](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedEvilInACan): A horrifying fiend that the cactuars managed to imprison centuries ago. The Machine Faction unwittingly freed it during their salvage excavations.

[Unique Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniqueEnemy): In a game that lavishes in [Underground Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndergroundMonkey) (that's why the Oversoul mechanic exists), Angra Mainyu is truly one of its kind.

[Zerg Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZergRush): It sics a horde of basilisk-type enemies at the Cactuar Nation. They are held at bay by Marnela until the Gullwings reunite all ten of her children. Those children then [unite their powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourPowersCombined) in a magical ritual that destroys the basilisks and blocks Angra Mainyu from attacking the cactuars. It angrily turns on the Machine Faction instead.
